title: International Traffic in Arms Regulations: Exemption for Defense Trade and Cooperation Among Australia, the United Kingdom, and the United States
summary: The Department of State proposes to amend the International Traffic in Arms Regulations (ITAR) to support the AUKUS partnership among Australia, the United Kingdom, and the United States. This amendment introduces an exemption to the requirement of obtaining a license or other approval for the export, reexport, retransfer, or temporary import of defense articles; the performance of defense services; or engagement in brokering activities among these nations. The rule aims to foster defense trade and cooperation, reflecting a commitment to shared security standards on protecting defense technology and sensitive military know-how.
affectedParties: Defense industry entities in Australia, the United Kingdom, and the United States
Government agencies involved in defense trade and cooperation in Australia, the United Kingdom, and the United States
keyChanges: Introduction of an exemption for license or approval requirements for defense trade among Australia, the United Kingdom, and the United States
Specification of defense articles and services excluded from the exemption
Inclusion of provisions for intra-company, intra-organization, and intra-governmental transfers to allow for the transfer of classified defense articles to certain dual nationals
Revision of the section on expediting license review applications to reference new processes for Australia, the United Kingdom, and Canada
exemptions_and_exceptions: A list of defense articles and services not eligible for the exemption
Exclusion of transfers that would require certification to Congress under sections 36(c) and 36(d) of the AECA
implementation_and_compliance: The exemption can only be used for transfers within the physical territory of Australia, the United Kingdom, or the United States
Eligible members, known as authorized users, will undergo an enrollment process
Transferors must maintain records of each transfer and make them available to the Directorate of Defense Trade Controls upon request
Transfers of classified defense articles and services must meet respective industrial security requirements
implications: Enhanced security cooperation and collaboration with Australia and the United Kingdom
Potential reduction in licensing burdens for some exporters
Faster adjudication of license applications involving Australia, the United Kingdom, or Canada when an ITAR exemption is not available
